para.text: When classes are installed from a source package each class object is sent the message #
once all of the methods have been compiled. A common use of the #

method is to set up class variables etc. It seems fairly likely that, when loading classes from a binary package, these may also need to be initialized in some situations. However, since a binary class comes with its state (i.e. class variables and so on) fully set up, it is not appropriate at this stage for it to receive another #
to each of the class objects that it installs.
Note that, if you browse the image for definitions of
, you'll find that it is very rare for a binary class to require initialization in this way.
